claim: AI does not inherently favor liberal democracy over authoritarianism; to avoid AI-enabled autocracy, democratic states should pursue an 'entente strategy' that secures AI supply chains, scales rapidly, restricts adversaries’ chip access, achieves military superiority, and pairs deterrence with broad benefit-sharing to tilt global governance toward democracy.
explanation: Evidence shows AI can bolster digital repression and censorship, so it doesn’t inherently favor liberal democracy; scholars also argue technology is not a natural ally of democracy. ([freedomhouse.org](https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2023/repressive-power-artificial-intelligence?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [cambridge.org](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/cambridge-handbook-of-responsible-artificial-intelligence/artificial-intelligence-and-the-past-present-and-future-of-democracy/B6A19E65F15179EC41AB226D24A9FC51?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) The recommended “entente”-style mix—ally coordination to secure AI/semiconductor supply chains, coordinated export controls to limit adversaries’ access to advanced chips, scaling and diffusion/benefit-sharing among partners, and pursuing an AI-enabled military edge—matches prominent policy analyses and ongoing U.S.–allied efforts. ([foreignaffairs.com](https://www.foreignaffairs.com/united-states/how-america-can-stay-ahead-china-ai-race?utm_source=chatgpt.com))
